Award.AwardTitle: Project S4 (Scholarships and Supports for STEM Success)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of Donnelly College's Project S4 (Scholarships and Supports for STEM Success) is to recruit, retain, and graduate students with majors in Information Systems and Biological/Physical Science. Towards this goal the project will support a total of 57 students in Associate of Applied Science (AAS), Associate in Science (AS) or Bachelor of Science (BS) degrees in the aforementioned disciplines, who have demonstrated financial need. Donnelly is located in an under-resourced urban area; to keep tuition low for its students, it operates out of a converted hospital building and has gradually upgraded so that learning spaces are pleasant and functional. The project will strive to prepare students for STEM careers while minimizing (or eliminating) college debt.

Specific objectives of Project S4 include: (1) increased enrollment of IS (AAS and BS) and of Biological/Physical Science (AS) students; (2) transfer of at least 90% of AS/AAS students into B.S. degree programs at Donnelly or other accredited institutions; (3) expansion of Supplemental Instruction (SI), undergraduate conference attendance, peer mentoring, and tutoring; (4) determination of effectiveness of service learning paired with either job shadowing or internships as professional experiences in STEM fields; and (5) strengthening of partnerships between Donnelly and local STEM-related companies. The project evaluation will strive to answer questions of interest to the broader STEM education community. In particular, these questions are related to the impact of support services on student success in terms of retention, graduation and transfer rates, and the impact of linked professional experiences on students' knowledge of and exposure to their STEM professions, confidence in their ability to succeed and motivation to persist in STEM majors.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project S4 (Scholarships and Supports for STEM Success) was designed to improve recruitment, retention and graduation rates for low-income, minority and first-generation STEM students, particularly students in Information Systems and Biological/Physical Science. The project supported associate degree students aspiring to complete STEM bachelor?s programs (at Donnelly College or another accredited institution) as well as bachelor?s students in our Information Systems program. In our initial proposal, we projected that Project S4 would support 57 students with scholarships of $4,000/year toward Donnelly?s modest private college tuition of $8,000/year. Donnelly serves an under-resourced urban community and annual household incomes for Donnelly students average just under $30,000. To promote access for these students, Donnelly keeps tuition as low as possible, preparing high-achieving students for STEM careers while minimizing (or eliminating) student loan debt.

 

Even after expanding S4 eligibility to include associate degree students in other STEM fields (IT and Math), we only provided scholarships to 31 unduplicated students?22 associate degree students and nine (9) bachelor?s degree students. Key barriers to recruiting and retaining S4 scholars included competition from more attractive internal and external scholarships for high-achieving minority STEM students, ineligibility for students who were not U.S. citizens or permanent residents, and the need for students to work to help support their families?preventing them from maintaining full-time enrollment or the required 3.0 STEM GPA.

 

  •  Of the 22 students that began receiving the S-STEM scholarship as associate degree students, 15 completed associate degrees, two are still enrolled in our associate degree program, three transferred into STEM associate degree programs at other institutions, and two left Donnelly before completing an associate degree.

 

  • Of the nine students that began receiving the S-STEM scholarship as bachelor?s degree students in our Information Systems program, six have already completed their B.S. in Information Systems, one will complete in December 2021, and two left Donnelly before completing their bachelor?s degree.

 

Our program also made progress toward key project goals:

 

  • Increase Biological/Physical Science and Information Systems enrollment by 50% - The number of students enrolled in Information Systems and Biological/Physical Science courses increased from 71 unduplicated students in fall 2014 (pre-grant) to 90 unduplicated students in fall 2020?a 27% increase. However, because overall enrollment at Donnelly declined from 422 students in fall 2014 to 350 students in fall 2020, the percentage of students enrolled in these STEM courses increased from 17% of all students in fall 2014 to 26% of all students in fall 2020.

 

  • Facilitate the transfer of 90% of associate degree graduates into accredited STEM bachelor?s programs - Eleven of the 15 (73%) S4 scholars who completed associate degrees at Donnelly during the grant term successfully transferred into STEM bachelor?s degree programs?five into our B.S. Information Systems program and six into STEM bachelor?s programs at other accredited institutions. Two of these transfer students have completed their programs, earning bachelor?s degrees in computer science and math/statistics, and the other three are still working toward their degrees.  

 

  •  Create a Supportive STEM Learning Community - In spring 2019, Donnelly administered a general survey that all STEM students were encouraged to complete. Each year, more than 75% of respondents reported improvement in STEM-related study skills, motivation to learn in STEM courses, and preparation for the next step in their education. More than 72% reported increased interest in STEM careers and more than 68% reported increased confidence that they could succeed in a STEM-related career.

 

  • Test Effect of Service-Learning and Internships on STEM Persistence - All S4 scholars are required to participate in service-learning through our STEM Club. Twelve of the fourteen S4 scholars who were enrolled in the IS program also completed an internship. Ten of these twelve have graduated with their B.S. in IS while two are on track to graduate by May 2022. Of the ten Information Systems graduates, nine were employed in STEM fields after graduation, suggesting a positive correlation between participating in service-learning and internships and persisting in STEM degree programs and career fields.

 

  • Strengthen Partnerships with Local STEM-related Companies - Each year Donnelly?s Career Services hosts an Internship Fair and recruits local employers to provide Mock Interview practice for students. In August 2020, Donnelly implemented a new platform called College Central Network. Fifty-six local employers and 131 students and alumni are actively using the platform.

 

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts: Project S4 demonstrated how providing targeted academic support resources and engaging students in service-learning and internships not only improved their performance in STEM courses, but also increased their persistence in STEM fields. Twenty-five of the 31 students (81%) supported by Project S4 were racial/ethnic minorities, including eight Hispanics, eight Asians, seven African Americans, and two multi-racial students. Improving persistence and completion for underrepresented racial/ethnic minorities in STEM degree programs increases their representation in STEM fields and positions them to serve as role models for their communities.


Last Modified: 06/30/2021
Modified by: Ana L Maradiaga

Donnelly serves an under-resourced urban community and annual household incomes for Donnelly students average just under $30,000. Twelve of the fourteen S4 scholars who were enrolled in the IS program also completed an internship. Ten of these twelve have graduated with their B.S. in IS while two are on track to graduate by May 2022. Twenty-five of the 31 students (81%) supported by Project S4 were racial/ethnic minorities, including eight Hispanics, eight Asians, seven African Americans, and two multi-racial students. Improving persistence and completion for underrepresented racial/ethnic minorities in STEM degree programs increases their representation in STEM fields and positions them to serve as role models for their communities.
